message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Policy Iteration Approach to the Infinite Horizon Average Optimal Control of Probabilistic Boolean Networks
Paper Abstract: This article studies the optimal control of probabilistic Boolean control networks (PBCNs) with the infinite horizon average cost criterion. By resorting to the semitensor product (STP) of matrices, a nested optimality equation for the optimal control problem of PBCNs is proposed. The Laurent series expression technique and the Jordan decomposition method derive a novel policy iteration-type algorithm, where finite iteration steps can provide the optimal state feedback law, which is presented. Finally, the intervention problem of the probabilistic Ara operon in E. coil, as a biological application, is solved to demonstrate the effectiveness and feasibility of the proposed theoretical approach and algorithms.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Here's what I found about Laurent Series:

## Overview

A Laurent series is a representation of a function as a power series which includes terms of negative degree.(no content)It may be used to express complex functions in cases where a Taylor series expansion cannot be applied.

## History

The Laurent series was named after and first published by Pierre Alphonse Laurent in 1843.(no content)Karl Weierstrass had previously described it in a paper written in 1841 but not published until 1894.

## Applications

Laurent series with complex coefficients are an important tool in complex analysis, especially to investigate the behavior of functions near singularities.(no content)Laurent series can be used to express holomorphic functions defined on an annulus, much as power series are used to express holomorphic functions defined on a disc.

## Key Properties

The Laurent series is unique.(no content)A Laurent polynomial is a Laurent series in which only finitely many coefficients are non-zero. Laurent polynomials differ from ordinary polynomials in that they may have terms of negative degree.(no content)The principal part of a Laurent series usually refers to the negative-power portion of the Laurent series of a function.

Web search results for query: "Jordan Decomposition"

Links: [{"title":"Jordan decomposition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jordan_decomposition"},{"title":"Jordan–Chevalley decomposition","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jordan–Chevalley_decomposition"},{"title":"Hahn decomposition theorem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hahn_decomposition_theorem"},{"title":"Jordan normal form - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jordan_normal_form"},{"title":"Jordan matrix - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jordan_matrix"},{"title":"Peirce decomposition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peirce_decomposition"},{"title":"Talk:Gaussian elimination - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Gaussian_elimination"},{"title":"Triple system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jordan_triple_system"},{"title":"Frobenius normal form - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rational_normal_form"},{"title":"Jordan–Pólya number - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jordan%E2%80%93P%C3%B3lya_number"}]

Based on the search results, "Jordan Decomposition" refers to several different mathematical concepts:

## Primary Meanings

**Jordan–Chevalley Decomposition**: In linear algebra, the Jordan–Chevalley decomposition expresses a linear operator in a unique way as the sum of two other linear operators—one part is potentially diagonalisable and the other is nilpotent.(no content)The two parts are polynomials in the operator, which makes them behave nicely in algebraic manipulations.(no content)The Jordan–Chevalley decomposition can be seen as a generalisation of the Jordan normal form.

**Jordan Decomposition (Measure Theory)**: In measure theory, the Jordan decomposition theorem states that every signed measure can be decomposed.(no content)The Jordan decomposition is unique, while the Hahn decomposition is only essentially unique.

**Jordan Normal Form**: Related to these decompositions, Jordan reduction states that any square matrix M can be written as a sum D + N where D is semisimple, N is nilpotent, and DN = ND, called the Jordan–Chevalley decomposition.

The term "Jordan Decomposition" most commonly refers to the Jordan–Chevalley decomposition in the context of linear algebra, named after mathematician Camille Jordan.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Web search results for query: "Policy Iteration"

Links: [{"title":"Markov decision process - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Markov_decision_process"},{"title":"State–action–reward–state–action","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State–action–reward–state–action"},{"title":"Reinforcement learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reinforcement_learning"},{"title":"Council for National Policy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Council_for_national_policy"},{"title":"Hollow state - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hollow_state"},{"title":"Life unworthy of life - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lebensunwertes_Leben"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about Policy Iteration:

## Overview

Policy iteration has two steps: (1) a value update and (2) a policy update, which are repeated in some order for all states until no further changes take place. Both recursively update a new estimation of the optimal policy and state value using an older estimation of those values.

## How It Works

In policy iteration, step one is performed once, and then step two is performed once, then both are repeated until policy converges.(no content)Instead of repeating step two to convergence, it may be formulated and solved as a set of linear equations, which are obtained by making the states equal in the step two equation.

## Comparison to Other Methods

Policy iteration is usually slower than value iteration for a large number of possible states.

## History

Policy iteration was invented by Howard to optimize Sears catalogue mailing, which he had been optimizing using value iteration.

## Modified Policy Iteration

In modified policy iteration, step one is performed once, and then step two is repeated several times. Then step one is again performed once and so on, with steps preferentially applied to states which are important either based on the algorithm or based on use.

Policy iteration is a fundamental algorithm in the field of dynamic programming and reinforcement learning, used to find optimal policies in Markov decision processes.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Here's information about **Escherichia coli**:

## Basic Overview

Escherichia coli is a gram-negative, facultative anaerobic, rod-shaped, coliform bacterium of the genus Escherichia that is commonly found in the lower intestine of warm-blooded organisms.(no content)E. coli is a bacterium that is normally found in the human intestine, but some strains of bacteria can cause illness and infection.

## Laboratory and Research Importance

E. coli K-12 and E. coli B strains are the most frequently used varieties for laboratory purposes.(no content)E. coli is the most widely studied prokaryotic model organism, and an important species in the fields of biotechnology and microbiology, where it has served as the host organism for the majority of work with recombinant DNA.

## Genome

The first complete DNA sequence of an E. coli genome (laboratory strain K-12 derivative MG1655) was published in 1997. It is a circular DNA molecule 4.6 million base pairs in length, containing 4288 annotated protein-coding genes (organized into 2584 operons), seven ribosomal RNA (rRNA) operons, and 86 transfer RNA (tRNA) genes.

## Pathogenic Strains

Some strains develop traits that can be harmful to a host animal. These virulent strains typically cause a bout of diarrhea that is often self-limiting in healthy adults but is frequently lethal to children in the developing world.(no content)In humans: gastroenteritis, urinary tract infection, and neonatal meningitis.

Web search results for query: "Optimal Control"

Links: [{"title":"Optimal control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Optimal_control"},{"title":"Pseudospectral optimal control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pseudospectral_optimal_control"},{"title":"Control (optimal control theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_(optimal_control_theory)"},{"title":"Unscented optimal control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unscented_optimal_control"},{"title":"Stochastic control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stochastic_control"},{"title":"Machine learning control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Machine_learning_control"},{"title":"Coherent control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coherent_control"},{"title":"H-infinity methods in control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/H-infinity_methods_in_control_theory"},{"title":"PROPT - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PROPT"},{"title":"Witsenhausen's counterexample - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Witsenhausen's_counterexample"}]

## Overview of Optimal Control

Optimal control theory is a branch of control theory that deals with finding a control for a dynamical system over a period of time such that an objective function is optimized.(no content)It has numerous applications in science, engineering and operations research.

### Key Concepts

A control problem includes a cost functional that is a function of state and control variables, and an optimal control is a set of differential equations describing the paths of the control variables that minimize the cost function.(no content)In optimal control theory, a control is a variable chosen by the controller or agent to manipulate state variables, similar to an actual control valve.

### Applications and Examples

For example, the dynamical system might be a spacecraft with controls corresponding to rocket thrusters, and the objective might be to reach the Moon with minimum fuel expenditure.(no content)Or the dynamical system could be a nation's economy, with the objective to minimize unemployment; the controls in this case could be fiscal and monetary policy.

### Mathematical Methods

The method is largely due to the work of Lev Pontryagin and Richard Bellman in the 1950s, after contributions to calculus of variations by Edward J. McShane.(no content)The optimal control can be derived using Pontryagin's maximum principle (a necessary condition also known as Pontryagin's minimum principle or simply Pontryagin's principle), or by solving the Hamilton–Jacobi–Bellman equation (a sufficient condition).

### Special Variants

The field includes specialized approaches such as:
- Stochastic control or stochastic optimal control, a sub field of control theory that deals with the existence of uncertainty either in observations or in the noise that drives the evolution of the system.
- Adaptive Dynamic Programming (ADP), also known as approximate dynamic programming or neuro-dynamic programming, is a machine learning control method that combines reinforcement learning with dynamic programming to solve optimal control problems for complex systems.

Web search results for query: "Boolean Network"

Links: [{"title":"Boolean network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boolean_network"},{"title":"Boolean - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boolean"},{"title":"Gene regulatory network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gene_regulatory_network"},{"title":"Logic synthesis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Logic_synthesis"},{"title":"Stochastic geometry models of wireless networks - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stochastic_geometry_models_of_wireless_networks"},{"title":"File:Hou710 BooleanNetwork.svg - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Hou710_BooleanNetwork.svg"},{"title":"Bayesian network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bayesian_network"},{"title":"Boolean circuit - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boolean_circuit"},{"title":"Functional completeness - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Complete_set_of_Boolean_operators"},{"title":"Subjective logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Subjective_logic"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about Boolean Networks:

## Definition

A Boolean network is a particular kind of sequential dynamical system, where time and states are discrete, with both the set of variables and the set of states in the time series having a bijection onto an integer series.

## Structure

A Boolean network consists of a discrete set of Boolean variables each of which has a Boolean function (possibly different for each variable) assigned to it which takes inputs from a subset of those variables and output that determines the state of the variable it is assigned to. This set of functions in effect determines a topology (connectivity) on the set of variables, which then become nodes in a network.

## Dynamics

Usually, the dynamics of the system is taken as a discrete time series where the state of the entire network at time t+1 is determined by evaluating each variable's function on the state of the network at time t. This may be done synchronously or asynchronously.

## Applications

Boolean networks have been used in biology to model regulatory networks.(no content)Stuart Kauffman was amongst the first biologists to use the metaphor of Boolean networks to model genetic regulatory networks.

## History and Research

The first Boolean networks were proposed by Stuart A. Kauffman in 1969, as random models of genetic regulatory networks but their mathematical understanding only started in the 2000s.

## Behavioral Modes

The stability of Boolean networks depends on the connections of their nodes. A Boolean network can exhibit stable, critical or chaotic behavior.

Links: [{"title":"Boolean network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boolean_network"},{"title":"Boolean - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boolean"},{"title":"Gene regulatory network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gene_regulatory_network"},{"title":"Logic synthesis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Logic_synthesis"},{"title":"Stochastic geometry models of wireless networks - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stochastic_geometry_models_of_wireless_networks"},{"title":"File:Hou710 BooleanNetwork.svg - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Hou710_BooleanNetwork.svg"},{"title":"Bayesian network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bayesian_network"},{"title":"Boolean circuit - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boolean_circuit"},{"title":"Functional completeness - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Complete_set_of_Boolean_operators"},{"title":"Subjective logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Subjective_logic"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about Boolean Networks:

## Definition

A Boolean network is a particular kind of sequential dynamical system, where time and states are discrete, with both the set of variables and the set of states in the time series having a bijection onto an integer series.

## Structure

A Boolean network consists of a discrete set of Boolean variables each of which has a Boolean function (possibly different for each variable) assigned to it which takes inputs from a subset of those variables and output that determines the state of the variable it is assigned to. This set of functions in effect determines a topology (connectivity) on the set of variables, which then become nodes in a network.

## Dynamics

Usually, the dynamics of the system is taken as a discrete time series where the state of the entire network at time t+1 is determined by evaluating each variable's function on the state of the network at time t. This may be done synchronously or asynchronously.

## Applications

Boolean networks have been used in biology to model regulatory networks.(no content)Stuart Kauffman was amongst the first biologists to use the metaphor of Boolean networks to model genetic regulatory networks.

## History and Research

The first Boolean networks were proposed by Stuart A. Kauffman in 1969, as random models of genetic regulatory networks but their mathematical understanding only started in the 2000s.

## Behavioral Modes

The stability of Boolean networks depends on the connections of their nodes. A Boolean network can exhibit stable, critical or chaotic behavior.

## Ara Operon Search Results

Here's information about the Ara Operon from the web search:

### Basic Definition
The L-arabinose operon, also called the ara or araBAD operon, is an operon required for the breakdown of the five-carbon sugar L-arabinose in Escherichia coli.

### Structural Components
The L-arabinose operon contains three structural genes: araB, araA, araD (collectively known as araBAD), which encode for three metabolic enzymes that are required for the metabolism of L-arabinose.(no content)AraB (ribulokinase), AraA (an isomerase), and AraD (an epimerase) produced by these genes catalyse conversion of L-arabinose to an intermediate of the pentose phosphate pathway, D-xylulose-5-phosphate.

### Gene Regulation
The expression of the L-arabinose operon is controlled as a single unit by the product of regulatory gene araC and the catabolite activator protein (CAP)-cAMP complex.(no content)AraC functions as a homodimer, which can control transcription of araBAD through interaction with the operator and the initiator region on L-arabinose operon.

### Regulatory Mechanism
Expression of the araBAD operon is activated in the absence of glucose and in the presence of arabinose. When arabinose is present, both AraC and CAP work together and function as activators.

### Research Applications
The L-arabinose operon has been commonly used in protein expression system, as the araBAD promoter can be used for producing targeted expression under tight regulation. By fusing the araBAD promoter to a gene of interest, the expression of the target gene can be solely regulated by arabinose: for example, the pGLO plasmid contains a green fluorescent protein gene under the control of the PBAD promoter, allowing GFP production to be induced by arabinose.

Links: [{"title":"Full state feedback - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Full_state_feedback"},{"title":"Feedback linearization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Feedback_linearization"},{"title":"Controllability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Controllability"},{"title":"State observer - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_observer"},{"title":"Control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory"},{"title":"Ackermann's formula - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ackermann's_formula"},{"title":"Linear–quadratic regulator - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear–quadratic_regulator"},{"title":"Robust control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robust_control"},{"title":"Feed forward (control) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Feed_forward_(control)"},{"title":"Linear–quadratic–Gaussian control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear–quadratic–Gaussian_control"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about State Feedback Control:

## Overview

Full state feedback (FSF), or pole placement, is a method employed in feedback control system theory to place the closed-loop poles of a plant in predetermined locations in the s-plane.(no content)Placing poles is desirable because the location of the poles corresponds directly to the eigenvalues of the system, which control the characteristics of the response of the system.

## Key Requirements

The system must be considered controllable in order to implement this method.(no content)Complete state controllability describes the ability of an external input (the vector of control variables) to move the internal state of a system from any initial state to any final state in a finite time interval.

## How It Works

Comparing the terms of the characteristic equation with those of the desired characteristic equation yields the values of the feedback matrix which force the closed-loop eigenvalues to the pole locations specified by the desired characteristic equation.

## Related Concepts

One approach involves creating a feedback loop with a gain k that will feed the state variable x into the input u, with the control input u(t) = r(t) − kx(t), such that the new dynamics of the system will be modified accordingly.(no content)The LQR algorithm is essentially an automated way of finding an appropriate state-feedback controller, and control engineers often prefer alternative methods like full state feedback, also known as pole placement, in which there is a clearer relationship between controller parameters and controller behavior.

Based on my search results, I did not find specific information about "Semitensor Product Matrix" as a distinct mathematical concept in the major mathematical references returned (Wikipedia articles on tensor products, Kronecker products, matrix products, etc.).

However, the search results show related concepts that may be relevant:

1. **Tensor Products**: The matrix describing the tensor product can be represented as the Kronecker product of two matrices.

2. **Kronecker Product**: The Kronecker product is an operation on two matrices of arbitrary size resulting in a block matrix, and is a specialization of the tensor product from vectors to matrices.

3. **Matrix Product States**: There is a concept in quantum physics called matrix product states, which uses matrices with entries being state vectors and multiplies matrices using tensor product for its entries instead of product of two complex numbers.

If you're looking for information about a specific "semitensor product," it may be a more specialized or newer mathematical concept not widely documented in standard references. This would help me search more effectively for the specific definition you're looking for.

Web search results for query: "Infinite Horizon Control"

Links: [{"title":"Optimal control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Optimal_control"},{"title":"Linear–quadratic regulator - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear–quadratic_regulator"},{"title":"Algebraic Riccati equation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Algebraic_Riccati_equation"},{"title":"H-infinity methods in control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/H-infinity_methods_in_control_theory"},{"title":"Moving horizon estimation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moving_horizon_estimation"},{"title":"Absolute horizon - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Absolute_horizon"},{"title":"Model predictive control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Model_predictive_control"},{"title":"Event horizon - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Event_horizon"},{"title":"Horizon - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Horizon"},{"title":"Cosmological horizon - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cosmological_horizon"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about Infinite Horizon Control:

## Overview

Infinite horizon control refers to a control system approach where the terminal time is taken in the limit as time approaches infinity (t_f → ∞).

## Linear Quadratic Regulator (LQR)

The most common application of infinite horizon control is in the **Linear Quadratic Regulator (LQR)** problem. In the LQR approach, all system matrices are constant, the initial time is arbitrarily set to zero, and the terminal time is taken in the limit of infinity.

The LQR minimizes an infinite horizon quadratic continuous-time cost functional that integrates state and control penalties from time 0 to infinity.

## Mathematical Solution

For infinite horizon LQR problems, the differential Riccati equation is replaced with the algebraic Riccati equation (ARE). The algebraic Riccati equation determines the solution of the infinite-horizon time-invariant Linear-Quadratic Regulator problem (LQR) as well as that of the infinite horizon time-invariant Linear-Quadratic-Gaussian control problem (LQG).

## Key Advantage

While the infinite horizon problem assumes the operator is driving the system to zero-state, the problem of driving the output to a desired nonzero level can be solved afterward, and it can be proved that this secondary LQR problem can be solved in a straightforward manner.

Infinite horizon control is fundamental in control theory and has numerous applications across engineering, science, and operations research.

Web search results for query: "Average Cost Control"

Links: [{"title":"Average cost method - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Average_cost_method"},{"title":"Inventory control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inventory_control"},{"title":"Cost of goods sold - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Production_cost"},{"title":"Average cost - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Average_cost"},{"title":"Average cost pricing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Average_cost_pricing"},{"title":"Process costing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Process_costing"},{"title":"Cost accounting - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cost_accounting"},{"title":"Optimal control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Optimal_control"},{"title":"Cost-plus pricing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cost-plus_pricing"},{"title":"Cost estimate - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cost_estimate"}]

Based on the search results, here's what "Average Cost Control" refers to:

## Overview

Average cost method is a method of accounting which assumes that the cost of inventory is based on the average cost of the goods available for sale during the period.

## How It Works

The average cost is computed by dividing the total cost of goods available for sale by the total units available for sale.(no content)This quantity is multiplied by weighted average cost per unit to give an estimate of ending inventory cost, while the cost of goods sold valuation is the amount of goods sold times the weighted average cost per unit.

## Moving-Average Method

The search results also describe a variation called the moving-average cost approach. During the year, multiple purchases are made, and each time purchase costs are added to beginning inventory cost to get cost of current inventory. Similarly, the number of units bought is added to beginning inventory to get current goods available for sale. After each purchase, cost of current inventory is divided by current goods available for sale to get current cost per unit on goods.

## Context in Business

The control of inventory involves managing the physical quantities as well as the costing of the goods as it flows through the supply chain. In managing the cost prices of the goods throughout the supply chain, several costing methods are employed.

The average cost method is commonly used as one of several accounting approaches, alongside methods like FIFO (First-In-First-Out) and LIFO (Last-In-First-Out).
